claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling in tumors.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) 3.1 vs 1.0
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination leads to a broader peptide repertoire on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome 62.3% vs 37.3%
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome 40.6% vs 20.6%

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: Patients with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination had improved survival under ICI treatment compared to unvaccinated patients.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value p=0.01
Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely. Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling is required for the observed tumor sensitization effect.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.

claims.caveat: Perturbation results may be model-specific and require confirmation across diverse tumor types.

claims.claim: The combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccination with checkpoint blockade increases immune cell infiltration into tumors.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change 1.8x vs 1.0x
Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy

claims.caveat: Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation in human settings.
